While it may still be a fair piece off the approach of Vernor Vinge's 'Technological Singularity' is messing with humanity's ability to cope with accelerating change.

Capitalism is supposed to adjust for the obsolescence of labor with recessions. When productivity of current labor exceeds the willingness to consume and inventories build up the less productive labor is freed up to learn new trades and go into other lines of production.

But if we do not have time to retrain workers for the new skills before the the next change we end up with a job market that looks like the panic scene from Hitchcock's Vertigo. The bottom recedes faster than we can fall.

When older workers lose jobs they don't have time to retrain. When the young leave college prepared for a job that is fading away what are they to do?

We hear every day there are millions of jobs going un filled because companies cannot find the skilled people they want to hire.

Perhaps we can beat this issue for one or two more rounds if we just find a way to train people in the process of how to learn and adapt as the technological world changes around them. But if the pace of change keeps accelerating the human mind will one day be unable to keep up.
